ARTICLE A: FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 2-2-1 FIRE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is established a City Fire Department to be headed by a Fire
Chief who shall be appointed by the City Manager.
   (B)   The City Manager may employ additional members of the department as is
deemed appropriate.
State Law Reference:
   Appointment of chief of fire department, S.C. Code § 5-25-110
   Authority to equip and control fire department, S.C. Code § 5-25-20
§ 2-2-2 TAMPERING WITH EQUIPMENT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with the fire reels or
appurtenances thereto, axes, tools, wrenches or any other fire fighting
equipment wherever located belonging to the city.
(1977 Code, § 2-2002)
§ 2-2-3 FALSE FIRE ALARM.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to make, report or turn in any false
alarm of fire.
(1977 Code, § 2-2003)
State Law Reference:
   Giving false alarms, S.C. Code § 16-17-570
§ 2-2-4 TAMPERING WITH ALARM SYSTEM.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper in any manner with the fire
alarm box, switch, wiring or any other portion of the fire alarm system.
(1977 Code, § 2004)
State Law Reference:
   Interference with fire alarm boxes, S.C. Code § 16-17-570
§ 2-2-5 DRIVING OVER FIRE HOSE.
   No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the Fire Department
when laid down on any street or private driveway, to be used at any fire or
alarm of fire, without the consent of the Fire Department official in command.
(1977 Code, § 2005)
ARTICLE B: FIRE PREVENTION CODE
Cross Reference:
   Burning trash, leaves and other refuse prohibited, Sec.
6-2-5
§ 2-2-11 ADOPTION OF FIRE PREVENTION CODE.
   There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of prescribing
regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or
explosion, that certain code known as the Fire Prevention Code recommended by
the American Insurance Association, being particularly the 1976 edition thereof
and the whole thereof, of which Code at least one (1) copy is filed in the
office of the Clerk and the Code is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as
if set out at length herein, and from date on which this ordinance shall take
effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the
city.
(1977 Code, § 2-2011)
State Law Reference:
   Adoption of Standard Code by reference, S.C. Code § 5-7-280
§ 2-2-12 ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES OF BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION.
   (A)   The Fire Prevention Code shall be enforced by the Bureau of Fire
Prevention in the Building Department of the city which is hereby established
and which shall be operated under the supervision of the Chief of the Fire
Department.
   (B)   The inspector in charge of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall be
appointed by the City Manager on the basis of examination to determine his
qualifications. His appointment shall continue during good behavior and
satisfactory service, and he shall not be removed from office except for cause.
   (C)   A report of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall be made annually and
transmitted to the City Manager; it shall contain all proceedings under this
Code, with statistics as the inspector in charge may wish to include therein;
the inspector in charge shall also recommend any amendments to the Code which,
in his judgment, shall be desirable.
(1977 Code, § 2-2012)
§ 2-2-13 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the Fire Prevention Code,
it shall be held to mean the City of Dillon, South Carolina.
   (B)   Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the Fire Prevention
Code, it shall be held to mean the City Attorney.
(1977 Code, § 2-2014)
§ 2-2-14 STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES.
   The limits referred to in section 12.5b of the Fire Prevention Code in which
storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established
as follows: all residentially zoned areas and B-1 Commercial areas.
(1977 Code, § 2-2014)
§ 2-2-15 STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS.
   (A)   The limits referred to in section 16.22a of the Fire Prevention Code
in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is
prohibited are hereby established as follows: bounded on the north by Cleveland
Street; on the south by Calhoun Street; on the east by Sixth Avenue and on the
west by Ninth Avenue.
   (B)   The limits referred to in section 16.61 of the Fire Prevention Code,
in which new bulk plans for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited,
are hereby established as follows: all residential zones and B-1 Commercial
zones.
(1977 Code, § 2-2015)
§ 2-2-16 STORAGE OF LIQUIFIED PETROLEUM GASES.
   The limits referred to in section 21.6a of the Fire Prevention Code, in
which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby
established as follows: all residential zones and B-1 Commercial zones.
(1977 Code, § 2-2016)
§ 2-2-17 ROUTES FOR VEHICLES TRANSPORTING EXPLOSIVES AND BLASTING AGENTS.
   The routes referred to in section 12.70 of the Fire Prevention Code for
vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are determined by the
inspector in charge of the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
(1977 Code, § 2-2017)
§ 2-2-18 ROUTES FOR VEHICLES TRANSPORTING HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS OR OTHER
DANGEROUS ARTICLES.
   The routes referred to in section 20.14 of the Fire Prevention Code for
vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles are
determined by the inspector in charge of the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
(1977 Code, § 2-2018)
§ 2-2-19 FIRE LANES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY, DEVOTED TO PUBLIC USE.
   All fire lanes must be a minimum of nine (9) feet in width. They should be
located in the area most immediately adjacent to the front of a building and be
marked so as to provide immediate ingress and egress of Fire Department
vehicles.
(1977 Code, § 2-2019)
§ 2-2-20 MODIFICATIONS.
   The inspector in charge of fire prevention shall have power to modify any of
the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code upon application in writing by the
owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical
difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the Code, provided
that the spirit of the Code shall be observed, public safety secured, and
substantial justice done. The particulars of the modification when granted or
allowed and the decision of the inspector in charge of fire prevention thereon
shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be
furnished the applicant.
(1977 Code, § 2-2020)
§ 2-2-21 APPEALS.
   Whenever the inspector in charge of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall
disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it
is claimed that the provisions of the Code do not apply or that the true intent
and meaning of the Code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the
applicant may appeal from the decision of the inspector in charge of the Bureau
of Fire Prevention to the Building Board of Adjustments and Appeals within
thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed.
(1977 Code, § 2-2011)
§ 2-2-22 NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES WHICH MAY REQUIRE PERMITS.
   The City Manager, the Chief of the Fire Department and the inspector in
charge of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall act as a committee to determine
and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new
materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits, and in
addition to those now enumerated in the Code. The inspector in charge of the
Bureau of Fire Prevention shall post the list in a conspicuous place in his
office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons.
(1977 Code, § 2-2022)
§ 2-2-23 LICENSES AND PERMITS.
   (A)   Permits covered in the Fire Prevention Code and required in various
articles are valid for a period of one (1) year from date of issuance. Annual
renewals of permits are the responsibility of the property owner or his agent
or operator.
   (B)   Any property owner or his agent or operator who is required to
purchase an annual business license can be issued a permit which is valid for
an indefinite period.
§ 2-2-24 PENALTIES.
   (A)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the Code hereby
adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply
with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed
statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any
certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been
taken, or who shall fail to comply with such order as affirmed or modified by
the Building Board of Adjustments or by a court of competent jurisdiction,
within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every violation and
noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of
not less than fifteen dollars ($15) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100) or
imprisonment for not less than five (5) days nor more than thirty (30) days or
by both the fine and imprisonment. The imposition of one (1) penalty for any
violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such
persons shall be required to correct or remedy the violations or defects within
a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that
prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the
enforced removal of prohibited conditions.
(1977 Code, § 2-2024)
ARTICLE C: FIREWORKS
§ 2-2-31 TIME RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   Any person may use, fire, shoot and/or discharge fireworks within
Residential Zoning Districts of the city limits after the hour of 8:00 a.m.
until 10:00 p.m. on any day of the week, Monday through Sunday of each year,
provided that the acts do not create a danger to public safety and/or result in
a nuisance so as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual or
citizen of the city.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use, fire, shoot and/or
discharge fireworks within the Residential Zoning Districts of the city limits
between the hours after 10:00 p.m. on any day of the week through 8:00 a.m. on
the following day, with the exception of the following holidays:
      (1)   New Year’s Eve, Christmas Eve and Independence Day Eve.
         (a)   Any person may use, fire, shoot and/or discharge fireworks
within Residential Zoning Districts on the eve of New Year’s Day, Christmas Day
and Independence Day of each year beginning at 8:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the
following day.
         (b)   It shall be prohibited and unlawful for any person to use, fire,
shoot and/or discharge fireworks between the early morning hours after 2:00
a.m. through 8:00 a.m. within Residential Zoning Districts on New Year’s Day,
Christmas Day and/or Independence Day.
      (2)   New Year’s Day, Christmas Day and Independence Day.
         (a)   Any person may use, fire, shoot and/or discharge fireworks on
New Year’s Day, Christmas Day and Independence Day of each year beginning at 8:
00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following day.
         (b)   It shall be prohibited and unlawful for any person to use, fire,
shoot and/or discharge fireworks between the early morning hours after 2:00
a.m. through 8:00 a.m. the following morning after New Year’s Day, Christmas
Day and/or Independence Day within Residential Zoning Districts.
      (3)   Memorial Day, Labor Day, General Election Day, Veteran’s Day,
Thanksgiving Day.
         (a)   Any person may use, fire, shoot and/or discharge fireworks on
the day of Memorial Day, Labor Day, General Election Day, Veterans Day and
Thanksgiving Day of each year beginning at 8:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the
following day.
         (b)   It shall be prohibited and unlawful for any person to use, fire,
shoot and/or discharge fireworks between the early morning hours after 2:00
a.m. through 8:00 a.m. on the following morning after Memorial Day, Labor Day,
General Election Day, Veterans Day and/or Thanksgiving Day.
(Ord. 12-14, passed 10-8-2012)
§ 2-2-32 ARTICLE NOT APPLICABLE TO TOY CAP PISTOLS, ETC.
   The provisions of this article shall not include nor prevent the sale,
possession or use of toy cap pistol or toy pistol paper caps which contain not
more than one-fifth (1/5) grain of explosive mixture, fireworks known as
"sparklers" or firecrackers commonly known as "Chinese firecrackers", which are
defined as follows: being not over one-quarter (1/4) inch outside diameter, not
over two (2) inches long and containing not over four (4) grains of explosive
composition. The sale, use and possession of any toy pistol, toy pistol paper
caps, sparklers and Chinese firecrackers, as above defined, shall be permitted
at all times.
(1977 Code, § 2-2032)
§ 2-2-33 MANUFACTURE AND SHIPMENT OUT OF STATE.
   Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the manufacture in
this city of fireworks or the storing, selling or offering for sale for
shipment out of the state of fireworks, the use of which is made unlawful in
this city.
(1977 Code, § 2-2033)
§ 2-2-34 USE IN APPROVED PUBLIC DISPLAYS OR EXHIBITS.
   It shall be lawful for any person to use fireworks in public displays or
exhibits when the person desiring to give them shall have first obtained
written approval therefore from the City Council. The City Council may, in its
absolute discretion, grant or refuse to grant the permission so applied for or
may grant it subject to restrictions and limitations as it may, in its absolute
discretion, deem to be in the interest of public safety in connection with the
display or exhibit.
(1977 Code, § 2-2034)
State Law Reference:
   Permit from city required to hold public display, S.C. Code § 23-35-60
§ 2-2-35 EXEMPTION OF CERTAIN CARRIERS.
   Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the use of signals
necessary for the safe operation of railroads, buses, trucks or boats, nor
shall the provisions of this article apply to any common carrier, while acting
as such, lawfully transporting or having custody of fireworks in interstate
commerce or for delivery within the state for lawful use.
(1977 Code, § 2-2035)
§ 2-2-36 USE, FIRE, SHOOT AND/OR DISCHARGE FIREWORKS NEAR SCHOOLS, HOSPITALS,
CHURCHES, LIBRARY, SANATORIUM OR COURT.
   It shall be prohibited and unlawful for any person to use, fire, shoot and/
or discharge fireworks at anytime such as to create excessive loud, disturbing
and unnecessary noises to any school, institution of learning, library,
sanatorium, hospital or court, while it is in session, or to any church during
church services, which interferes with the work or worship in the place or
institution; provided that signs must be displayed indicating that it is a
school, hospital, church, library, sanatorium or court.
(Ord. 12-14, passed 10-8-2012)
§ 2-2-37 VIOLATIONS.
   Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty
of an offense and shall be subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars
($500) or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days upon conviction. Each
day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. Punishment for
violation shall be considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 12-14, passed 10-8-2012)

2-3-14   Administration of List
2-3-15   Response only upon Police Request
2-3-16   Owner of Vehicle to Choose Service
2-3-17   Time Limit for Service Requested by Owner
2-3-18   Recommendation by Police Officer Prohibited
2-3-19   Unavailability
2-3-20   Response Time: Notification of Next Service
2-3-21   When Several Vehicles are Involved in an Accident
2-3-22   Assistance from Other Wrecker Services
2-3-23   Conduct of Wrecker Operators
2-3-24   Wrecker Operator to Secure Personal Property
2-3-25   Complaints Involving the Rotation List
ARTICLE A
§ 2-3-1 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   The following regulations in this chapter shall be adhered to by all wrecker
services utilized by the City of Dillon.
§ 2-3-2 REMOVAL FROM ROTATION LIST.
   Failure of any wrecker service to comply with the regulations contained
herein may result in their removal from the City of Dillon's wrecker rotation
list by the Business License Administrator.
§ 2-3-3 INDEMNIFICATION.
   The wrecker company agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the City of
Dillon, it's employees, agents and assigns from suit, and claims or action of
every nature and description brought for, or on account of or sustained by any
person or persons as a result of any act or acts of the wrecker company, it's
employees, agents or assigns in the performance of services under the terms of
this agreement.
§ 2-3-4 POLICE REGULATIONS.
   No wrecker shall be driven or operated in a manner as to interfere with the
duties of police officers investigating accidents. Directions of police shall
be obeyed at all times and any licensed wrecker will promptly furnish service
when requested to do so by the police in order to clear traffic and promote
public safety.
§ 2-3-5 RIGHT OF INSPECTION.
   The City of Dillon Police Chief or his designee shall have the right, at any
time to enter into or upon, any wrecker or tow-in lot participating in the
rotation program, for the purpose of inspecting the wrecker, it's equipment and
any vehicle storage areas, to ensure public safety and adherence to the
provisions of this ordinance.
ARTICLE B: REQUIREMENTS
§ 2-3-6 FINANCIAL INTEREST OF POLICE OFFICER PROHIBITED.
   No City of Dillon police officer shall hold any financial interest or any
form of ownership interest in any wrecker service.
§ 2-3-7 ELIGIBILITY FOR CITY OF DILLON WRECKER ROTATION LIST.
   (A)   Any wrecker service which possesses a valid City of Dillon business
license located within three (3) miles from the city limits of Dillon is
eligible to be place on the wrecker rotation list. If a wrecker fails to
respond to calls for service within fifteen (15) minutes from the time it is
notified on three (3) separate occasions within a twelve (12) month time
period, the wrecker service will be automatically removed from the wrecker
rotation list regardless if the wrecker is located within three (3) miles from
the city and possesses a valid City of Dillon business license.
   (B)   A city business license is not required of a wrecker service at the
request of the owner or driver of a wrecked or disabled vehicle when there is
nothing to indicate that the service was anything other than an isolated,
incidental or casual one. Repeated services by a wrecker shall be considered as
engaging in business and shall be required to obtain a business license.
§ 2-3-8 AVAILABILITY.
   Wrecker services shall be available to the Police Department and the public
on a twenty-four (24) hour, seven (7) day a week basis.
§ 2-3-9 STORAGE AREA.
   Wrecker service shall maintain a safe and secured storage area for all
vehicles towed. This may be a locked building or a fenced in area where the
stored vehicle and other property shall not be accessible to the public.
§ 2-3-10 EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   All wreckers shall be equipped with legally authorized lighting and
other safety equipment to protect the motoring public. Such equipment shall be
maintained in good working order.
   (B)   Equipment such as brooms, shovels, etc., must be carried on all
wreckers in order to remove glass and other debris from the highway. It is the
responsibility of the wrecker service to clean the highway prior to leaving the
scene of any accident.
   (C)   The wrecker service must have equipment of sufficient size to handle
disabled vehicles of the type commonly used on South Carolina highways as
passenger cars, pick-up trucks, etc. Any additional equipment specified by the
South Carolina Highway Patrol for wrecker services must also be maintained by
those wrecker services on the City of Dillon wrecker rotation list.
§ 2-3-11 SIGNS.
   Each wrecker service on the rotation list must place a sign on the door of
each of its wreckers indicating the name, address and phone number of the
service. This sign shall be painted on the door of the wrecker or otherwise
permanently affixed to the door. The letters of the sign must be no less than
two (2) inches high. If the wrecker is registered in a name other than that of
the wrecker service, the owner's name must also appear on the door in letters
no less than one (1) inch high. All lettering on wreckers shall be plainly
visible and shall be in a color which contrasts to that of the wrecker.
§ 2-3-12 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   (A)   Any wrecker service on the rotation list shall carry liability
insurance on its wreckers and its premises in an amount not less than three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for a standard wrecker, seven hundred and
fifty thousand dollars ($750,000) for a heavy duty wrecker and must submit
evidence of such insurance to the City Business License Administrator.
   (B)   Any wrecker service on the rotation list shall carry garage keepers
liability insurance covering customer's vehicles in an amount not less than one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) and must submit evidence of such insurance
to the City Business License Administrator.
§ 2-3-13 CHARGES.
   Charges for work performed must be reasonable.
ARTICLE C: PROCEDURES
§ 2-3-14 ADMINISTRATION OF LIST.
   The wrecker rotation list shall be administered fairly and in a manner
designed to ensure that all wrecker services on the list have an equal
opportunity to the towing business as generated by the City of Dillon Business
License Administrator and the Dillon County E-911 dispatcher’s office.
§ 2-3-15 RESPONSE ONLY UPON POLICE REQUEST.
   Wreckers shall only respond upon request of the proper police authority.
Response under any other condition may result in removal from the wrecker
rotation list.
§ 2-3-16 OWNER OF VEHICLE TO CHOOSE SERVICE.
   Unless the owner or driver of a vehicle is incapacitated or unavailable, the
owner or driver of a wreck or disabled vehicle shall have the right to the
wrecker service of his or her choice. Before calling any wrecker service to tow
a wrecked or disabled vehicle, the investigating officer on the scene, if
practical, shall determine the owner's or driver's preference of wrecker
services, and the wrecker service designated by the owner shall be called. A
"City of Dillon Police Department Wrecker Service Request" form will be
completed by the investigating officer on the scene, whenever the normal
wrecker rotation is not followed as a result of an owner’s request. Officers
will not recommend any wrecker service and will not carry any information
concerning wrecker companies in their assigned police vehicles. Any information
concerning a particular wrecker service will be provided only by the driver or
owner of the vehicle to be towed who is solely responsible for requesting such
service.
§ 2-3-17 TIME LIMIT FOR SERVICE REQUESTED BY OWNER.
   Any wrecker service which is not on the rotation list and that is requested
to respond to the scene of an accident by the owner or operator of a disabled
or wrecked vehicle may respond when requested, so long as the wrecker responds
within fifteen (15) minutes from the time it is notified. A city business
license is not required of a wrecker service when there is nothing to indicate
that the service was anything other than an isolated, incidental or casual one.
Repeated services by a wrecker shall be considered as engaging in business and
shall be required to obtain a business license.
§ 2-3-18 RECOMMENDATION BY POLICE OFFICER PROHIBITED.
   In no event shall any Dillon police officer recommend any wrecker service to
the owner of a wrecked or disabled vehicle, nor shall any Dillon police officer
ever recommend the services of any particular wrecker service in the
performance of his duties.
§ 2-3-19 UNAVAILABILITY.
   When a wrecker service or wrecker driver is unable to answer a call, police
shall be promptly notified of that fact and the reason for the unavailability.
§ 2-3-20 RESPONSE TIME: NOTIFICATION OF NEXT SERVICE.
   If a wrecker does not respond within fifteen (15) minutes, the dispatcher
shall notify the next wrecker service on the list which shall not lose its
place in the rotation. Any wrecker failing to respond within this time period
on three (3) separate occasions within a twelve (12) month time period, will
automatically be removed from the rotation list.
§ 2-3-21 WHEN SEVERAL VEHICLES ARE INVOLVED IN AN ACCIDENT.
   When two (2) or more vehicles are involved in an accident and towing
services are required, the police officer on the scene will assign each wrecker
a specific vehicle to be towed unless the owner or driver of such vehicle has a
preference for a particular wrecker service.
§ 2-3-22 ASSISTANCE FROM OTHER WRECKER SERVICES.
   A wrecker service may secure assistance from other wrecker services when
necessary to do the job. Only one (1) bill is to be submitted to the owner or
operator of the towed vehicle for the work performed.
§ 2-3-23 CONDUCT OF WRECKER OPERATORS.
   Wrecker operators must conduct themselves in a proper manner at all accident
scenes and when dealing with the public.
§ 2-3-24 WRECKER OPERATOR TO SECURE PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   Each wrecker service shall be responsible for securing personal property in
a vehicle which is to be towed, in a reasonable and prudent manner. In no event
shall a wrecker service be responsible for personal items which do not come
into possession of the wrecker services.
§ 2-3-25 COMPLAINTS INVOLVING THE ROTATION LIST.
   (A)   Any complaints from wrecker services regarding the operation of the
City of Dillon rotation list must be submitted in writing and received by the
Business License Administrator within thirty (30) days of the incident.
   (B)   That this ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
the earliest date permitted by law.

§ 3-1-1 DUTIES OF THE SERVICE DEPARTMENT DIRECTOR.
   The Service Department Director shall be responsible for the maintenance and
cleaning of all streets and public grounds. The Director, in addition to the
foregoing, shall keep the openings of the public drains and the gutters along
the sidewalks clean and free from obstructions.
Cross Reference:
   Collection of garbage, Sec.
6-2-1 et seq.
§ 3-1-2 CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS.
   No sidewalk of any description shall be built by any person of any brick,
wood, or other material, without a written permit signed by the City Manager or
his designate. The construction of the sidewalk shall then be under the
supervision of the Director of the Service Department and shall be carried out
according to his instructions. The failure to obtain a permit before beginning
a sidewalk shall constitute a misdemeanor.
§ 3-1-3 BREAKING OR DESTROYING CURBING; CONSTRUCTING ENTRANCES INTO PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to break or destroy the curbing of any
street of the city, or to otherwise deface the curb, or to construct any
entrance into property on any of the paved streets of the city, unless the
person shall have first obtained a permit so to do from the City Manager or his
designate.
§ 3-1-4 EXCAVATIONS GENERALLY.
   Any person wishing to cut, dig, or ditch across or in any street or sidewalk
or alleyway, for any purpose, shall first obtain the written permission of the
City Manager or his designate and then shall leave the area in good and
passable condition. Failure to obtain permission before so digging or ditching
in or across any sidewalk, street, or alley or failure to leave the digging or
cutting in a passable condition shall constitute a violation of this section.
§ 3-1-5 LIGHTS ON EXCAVATIONS AND OBSTRUCTIONS REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any trench, ditch or excavation
in any street, sidewalk or public place of the city to remain open between
sunset and sunrise or to allow any obstruction, building material, scaffold,
impediment or obstacle to remain in or upon any street, sidewalk or public
place in the city between sunset and sunrise, unless the obstruction, building
material, scaffold, impediment, obstacle, trench, ditch or excavation has
sufficient number of lights properly displayed around it as danger signals to
prevent accidents to persons or property.
(1977 Code, § 3-1005)
§ 3-1-6 REMOVAL OF LIGHTS FROM EXCAVATIONS AND OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or extinguish any light which
may be placed as a signal at night to warn persons of danger from ditches,
trenches, excavations, building materials, scaffolds, impediments or obstacles
of any description whatever, within the corporate limits of the city.
(1977 Code, § 3-1006)
§ 3-1-7 TRIMMING SHADE TREES.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Am. Ord. 03-02, passed 3-10-
2003.)
§ 3-1-8 PARADES.
   (A)   No parade, excepting the forces of the Unites States Army or Navy, the
military forces of this state, and the forces of the Police and Fire
Departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in
accordance with a permit issued by the City Manager or his designate.
   (B)   In deciding whether to issue a permit under this section, the City
Manager or his designate shall consider:
      (1)   The number of persons to participate;
      (2)   The anticipated traffic conditions at the time and date proposed
for the activity;
      (3)   The schedule of other similar activities for which permits may have
been issued;
      (4)   The adequacy of adult supervision for any minor scheduled to
participate;
      (5)   The availability of city personnel whose presence on duty may be
required by the activity and by the necessity to protect the general public;
and
      (6)   The adequacy of public facilities in the location proposed for the
activity to accommodate the proposed activity and the normal public use of
public facilities in the proposed location.
§ 3-1-9 DUTY OF OCCUPANTS TO KEEP ADJACENT SIDEWALKS FREE FROM OBSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Every occupant of a lot on any street within the jurisdiction of the
city limits shall keep the sidewalk clear and free from obstruction as far as
the lot extends (with the exception of sidewalk sales permitted within the
designated Dillon Downtown Commercial Historic Overlay District in accordance
with §
5-4-70(A)(7)). The gutter shall remain open and free from obstruction as far as
the lot extends.
   (B)   If the space is not so kept clear and free and open from obstruction
of any kind (with the exception of sidewalk sales permitted within the
designated Dillon Downtown Commercial Historic Overlay District in accordance
with §
5-4-70(A)(7) for a period of twelve (12) hours after notice from the Police
Department, the occupant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1977 Code, § 3-1009) (Am. Ord. 18-03, passed 5-14-2018)
§ 3-1-10 OBSTRUCTIONS ON STREETS.
   No brick, stone, wood or other substance obstructing the free passage of
persons and vehicles shall be placed or suffered to lie in any of the streets
or alleys of the city. No person shall place on or in any of the streets,
sidewalks or alleys of the city any box, crates, casks or barrels of any
description or any other obstruction of any kind. However, any person erecting
a building may, with the permission of the City Manager or his designate, place
building materials for immediate use on the streets in a way as not to
interfere with the usual traffic.
(1977 Code, § 3-1010)
§ 3-1-11 STANDS AND BOXES ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or have placed any stands,
boxes or other structures upon the streets and sidewalks of the city (with the
exception of sidewalk sales permitted within the designated Dillon Downtown
Commercial Historic Overlay District in accordance with §
5-4-70(A)(7).
(1977 Code, § 3-1011) (Ord. 16-13, passed 11-14-2016; Am. Ord. 18-03, passed 5-
14-2018)
§ 3-1-12 AWNINGS AND WOODEN SHEDS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or repair over any sidewalk or
street any wooden shed or awning or any wooden shed for the support of an
awning, or erect upon any street or sidewalk any post for the support of any
awning. If any person shall violate this section, then each day that the above
forbidden obstruction shall remain, after notice, shall constitute a separate
violation of this section; provided, that this section shall not be construed
to prevent the erection over the sidewalk of cloth awnings, supported upon
metallic frames, firmly suspended from the building; provided further, that the
City Manager shall have the power to condemn and order removed any wooden
awnings now existing when they shall become dangerous or unsightly or in any
way detrimental to the public health or public safety of life and limb.
§ 3-1-13 THROWING, SWEEPING, OR BURNING TRASH ON SIDEWALKS OR STREETS.
   No paper, straw, lemon peel, banana peel, watermelon rind, or any trash of
any kind shall be thrown or swept upon any sidewalk or street of the city, nor
shall any trash, refuse or rubbish be burnt thereon. All trash shall be placed
in barrels and cans and left convenient for collection by city trucks.
( 1977 Code, § 3-1013)
Cross Reference:

6-2-1 et seq.
   Litter, Sec.
6-3-3 et seq.
§ 3-1-14 RIDING OR DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall lead or drive any horse or other animal, or drive any
automobile on any sidewalk of the city, except at an established crossing, nor
ride any bicycle thereon. Nothing in this section shall be construed as
preventing the use of the sidewalk for baby carriages, wheelchairs or
children's tricycles. (1977 Code, § 3-1015)

8-1-1 et seq.
§ 3-1-15 THROWING TACKS AND NAILS ON STREETS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any tacks, nails, glass bottles
or any other substances whatsoever upon the streets of the city that would or
tend to injure, cut or mutilate any property of another, whether tires,
livestock or other things.
(1977 Code, § 3-1016)
§ 3-1-16 DOORS AND GATES SWINGING OUTWARD OVER SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or occupying any premises
adjacent to sidewalks to allow any doors or gates to swing outward over the
sidewalk so as to obstruct the free passage thereon.
(1977 Code, § 3-1017)
§ 3-1-17 DAMAGING PARKWAYS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon, walk, ride, cross or
allow any horse or other animal, automobile or other vehicle to pass over,
stand upon or otherwise trespass on any of the parkways in the city, or to
pick, damage or injure any flowers, shrubbery or grass growing on the parkways.
For the purpose of this section, the word "parkway" shall be taken to mean all
that portion of a street lying between the street curbing at the edge of the
roadway and the paved portion of the sidewalk.
(1977 Code, § 3-1018)
§ 3-1-18 ALLOWING WATER FROM ROOF TO RUN ON SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to build, construct, erect or maintain a
house or building of any description in the city in a manner that rain water
may flow from the roof, eaves, cornices, gutters or other part thereof, down
upon any sidewalk so as to cause holes, depressions, unevenness, gullies or
other defects or damage to the sidewalk.
(1977 Code, § 3-1019)
§ 3-1-19 BREAKING OR REMOVING STREET LIGHTS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to break any lamp or electric light or
to remove any electric light bulb from any of the street lights within the
corporate limits of the city.
(1977 Code, § 3-1021)
§ 3-1-20 STREET NAMES.
   No person shall name any street or change the name of any street except in
accordance with the procedure outlined in the city subdivision regulations for
naming or renaming streets.
Cross Reference:

5-7-1 et seq.
