ARTICLE A: POOLROOMS AND BOWLING ALLEYS
§ 7-4-1 PLAYING WHEN PLACE IS CLOSED.
   No person operating a pocket billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley in the
city shall allow play on any table or at any alley when the place is closed.
(1977 Code, § 7-4001)
§ 7-4-2 MINORS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, owner or operator of a pocket
billiard room or poolroom in the city to allow any person under eighteen (18)
years of age to loiter in the pocket billiard room or poolroom or to play
pocket billiard or pool, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
   (B)   The burden of proof shall rest with the operator or owner of the
pocket billiard room or poolroom, that the person is so desiring to participate
shall come within the required age limits of this section.
State Law Reference:
   Minors on poolroom premises, S.C. Code § 20-7-8910
§ 7-4-3 PLAYING OR LOITERING BY INTOXICATED PERSONS.
   No person operating a pocket billiard room, poolroom, or bowling alley in
the city shall allow any person who is intoxicated to play or loiter in or on
the premises.
(1977 Code, § 7-4003)
§ 7-4-4 BETTING POOLS.
   No racing, football parley or other betting pool shall be allowed, promoted
or sold in a pocket billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley.
(1977 Code, § 7-4004)
"Cross Reference:
   Gambling prohibited generally, Sec.
9-4-1,
9-4-2
State Law Reference:
   Gambling and lotteries, S.C. Code §§ 16-19-10 et seq.
§ 7-4-5 LOUD OR PROFANE LANGUAGE.
   No loud, profane, obscene or indecent language shall be permitted in any
pocket billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley.
(1977 Code, § 7-4005)
§ 7-4-6 OPERATION ON GROUND FLOOR; PLATE GLASS WINDOWS.
   No pocket billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley shall be operated in the
city by any person except upon the ground floor of a building. Plate glass
windows shall be in the part of the building facing the street so that the
public shall at all times be able to see within the room.
(1977 Code, § 7-4006)
§ 7-4-7 SCREENS, CURTAINS AND PARTITIONS.
   No person operating a pocket billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley in the
city shall allow or permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions or other
obstructions to be placed between the entrance of the room where billiards or
pool are played and the back of the rear wall of the billiard room. A clear
view of the entire interior from the entrance to the rear of the room must be
maintained at all times. No partitions forming rooms, stalls, or other
enclosures where the public congregates shall be permitted. This section shall
not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of closets for storing purposes
exclusively or toilets.
(1977 Code, § 7-4007)
§ 7-4-8 CONNECTION WITH GAMBLING OR IMMORAL ESTABLISHMENT.
   No person operating a billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley in the city
shall maintain or permit to be maintained, any open or secret connections
through doors, windows or trap doors, panels, stairways or other devices with
any place where gambling is conducted or where persons congregate for immoral
purposes.
(1977 Code, § 7-4008)
§ 7-4-9 OPERATING TIME.
   (A)   All bowling alleys and skating rinks are required to close their doors
for business at 12 midnight each night.
   (B)   All poolrooms shall be closed at 11:00 p.m. each night and remain
closed until 6:00 a.m. the following morning, and shall not operate on Sundays.
ARTICLE B: MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS
§ 7-4-21 TRAVELING SHOWS.
   All sponsors of shows, rides, concessions or amusements of any nature shall
make application to and receive permission to locate within the city limits at
least ten (10) days prior to the date of the location or operation.
(1977 Code, § 4010)
State Law Reference:
   Circuses, carnivals and other traveling shows, S.C. Code §§ 52-1-20 et seq.
CHAPTER 5: TAXICABS
Section
7-5-1   Insurance Policy or Bond
7-5-2   Filing of Schedule of Rates
7-5-3   Permit Required
7-5-4   Application
7-5-5   Revocation
§ 7-5-1 INSURANCE POLICY OR BOND.
   No taxicab operator's business license shall be issued unless the applicant
therefor shall have filed with the City Manager a general liability insurance
policy or a bond in such amounts as required by state law for each taxicab to
be operated under the license.
State Law Reference:
   Bodily injury and property damage limits, S.C. Code § 58-23-1220
§ 7-5-2 FILING OF SCHEDULE OF RATES.
   Each taxicab operator shall, upon request of the Council, file with the City
Manager a schedule of rates to be charged passengers.
§ 7-5-3 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Each driver of a taxicab shall be required to have a taxicab driver's permit
issued by the City Manager before driving any taxicab on the streets of the
city. The taxicab driver's permit shall be valid for one (1) calendar year,
beginning July 1, and shall expire on the same date as the business license.
The taxicab permit shall be purchased at the cost of twenty-five dollars ($25).
(Ord. 97-07, passed 3-10-1997)
§ 7-5-4 APPLICATION.
   Before a taxicab driver's permit is issued by the City Manager, an
application therefor must be filed with the City Manager, showing good
character on the part of the applicant and the application must be approved by
the City Manager.
§ 7-5-5 REVOCATION.
   A taxicab driver's permit issued under this chapter shall be automatically
revoked upon conviction of the holder thereof of the violation of any state,
federal, or municipal penal law or ordinance relating to traffic or parking.
CHAPTER 6: FRANCHISES
Editorial Note: The Council, by ordinance, has granted a CATV franchise to the
Border Broadcasting Company, Inc.
Section
7-6-1   Utilities to Secure Franchise
7-6-2   Franchise Fees
7-6-3   Notification to Utilities; Negotiation of Franchise Agreements
§ 7-6-1 UTILITIES TO SECURE FRANCHISE.
   All utility companies shall secure a franchise agreement from the city for
the use of public rights-of-way within the city for the purpose of erecting,
constructing, maintaining and operating facilities thereon and thereunder,
according to existing city codes and ordinances, and any other special
franchise agreements which may be separately negotiated.
(Ord. CM-30, passed 2-1985)
§ 7-6-2 FRANCHISE FEES.
   Except for companies with provisions in contracts in existence on the
effective date of this section, all utility companies, in return for the right
to use rights-of-way, shall pay a franchise fee of three percent (3%) of gross
subscriber revenues to the city. Upon the expiration of the current contracts,
however, the franchise business shall immediately fall under the provisions of
this article.
(Ord. CM-30, passed 2-1985)
§ 7-6-3 NOTIFICATION TO UTILITIES; NEGOTIATION OF FRANCHISE AGREEMENTS.
   The City Manager and Finance Director are hereby authorized and directed to
notify the respective utility companies of the provisions of this article and
to negotiate any and all other additional provisions of a franchise agreement
which will be necessary and proper for the implementation of this article.
(Ord. CM-30, passed 2-1985)
CHAPTER 7: YARD SALES
Section
7-7-1   Definition
7-7-2   Time Restrictions
7-7-3   Traffic and Parking
7-7-4   Signs; Advertising
7-7-5   Display of Merchandise
7-7-6   Commercial Promotion of Sale Activity
7-7-7   Inspection for Violation
7-7-8   Penalty
§ 7-7-1 DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this chapter, a "yard sale" is defined as the sale or
trading of clothing, furniture, household items, food dishes, antiques or
similar goods or merchandise, other than in the normal course of business, or
the sale or trading of such goods, as outlined above, by a person not regularly
engaged in such business. Such goods or merchandise do not need to be attended
for a sale to be deemed to be in existence. The term "yard sale" shall include
garage sales, carport sales and similar types of sales or events.
§ 7-7-2 TIME RESTRICTIONS.
   Yard sales shall be allowed for not more than a total of three (3)
consecutive days and shall be limited to four (4) sales per location per year.
Sales shall be limited to the hours between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m.. A yard
sale permit is required prior to each sale.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 3-10-1997)
§ 7-7-3 TRAFFIC AND PARKING.
   The individual in charge of the premises upon which the sale is conducted
shall control the parking of vehicles of patrons so as to avoid congestion and
hazardous conditions. Failure to do so shall be sufficient cause for the sale
to be immediately terminated by officials of the city.
§ 7-7-4 SIGNS; ADVERTISING.
   Signs advertising or calling attention to or giving directions to a yard
sale shall be restricted to five (5) signs, non-illuminated, not to exceed two
(2) square feet. It shall be the responsibility of the holder of the sale to
remove the signs at the conclusion of the yard sale.
§ 7-7-5 DISPLAY OF MERCHANDISE.
   All displays of yard sale merchandise shall be limited to that portion of
the front yard area which is at least five (5) feet back from the property line
on all sides, and ten feet back from any curb or road edge.
§ 7-7-6 COMMERCIAL PROMOTION OF SALE ACTIVITY.
   No individual, firm, corporation, or partnership shall engage in the
business of promoting or conducting yard sales for others for a fee or other
consideration. No merchandise shall be purchased in anticipation of resale at a
yard sale. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent a person from
advertising in a newspaper concerning his yard sale.
§ 7-7-7 INSPECTION FOR VIOLATION.
   Violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in
§
1-3-48 of this Code; each day of violation shall be considered a separate
offense.
§ 7-7-8 PENALTY.
   Please refer to §
1-3-48.
CHAPTER 8: LOCAL ACCOMMODATIONS TAX
Section
7-8-1   Tax Imposed
7-8-2   Payment
7-8-3   Failure to Remit
7-8-4   Local Accommodations Tax Account
7-8-5   Separability
7-8-6   Date passed
§ 7-8-1 TAX IMPOSED.
   There is hereby imposed a Local Accommodations Tax of three percent (3%) on
the gross proceeds derived from rental or charges for accommodations furnished
to transients for consideration, as described in S.C. Code § 12-36-920(A), by a
person within the City of Dillon (hereinafter "vendor").
(Ord. 99-13, passed 9-13-1999)
§ 7-8-2 PAYMENT.
   Payment of the accommodations tax established herein shall be remitted by
the vendor to the City of Dillon on a monthly basis, along with the return or
form established by the city for such purposes, not later than the 15th day of
the month and shall cover the tax due for the previous month. Any tax not
timely remitted shall be subject to a penalty of five percent (5%) of the sum
owed for each month or portion thereof until paid.
(Ord. 99-13, passed 9-13-1999)
§ 7-8-3 FAILURE TO REMIT.
   The failure of any vendor subject to this ordinance to remit to the city the
tax imposed by the provisions of this ordinance shall constitute a misdemeanor
punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred ($500) or imprisonment or
both.
(Ord. 99-13, passed 9-13-1999)
§ 7-8-4 LOCAL ACCOMMODATIONS TAX ACCOUNT.
   There is hereby established a special account to be known as the Local
Accommodations Tax Account into which the taxes remitted shall be deposited by
the city and used solely for the purposes provided by law, which include the
following:
   (A)   Tourism related buildings;
   (B)   Cultural, recreational or historic facilities;
   (C)   Beach access and renourishment;
   (D)   Highways, roads, streets and bridges accessing tourist areas ;
   (E)   Advertisements and promotions related to tourism-related demand.
(Ord. 99-13, passed 9-13-1999)
§ 7-8-5 SEPARABILITY.
   This ordinance is subject to the constitution and laws of the State of South
Carolina. If any section, phrase, sentence or portion of this ordinance is for
any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions thereof.
(Ord. 99-13, passed 9-13-1999)
§ 7-8-6 DATE PASSED.
   This ordinance shall become effective October 1, 1999.
(Ord. 99-13, passed 9-13-1999)
CHAPTER 9: LOCAL HOSPITALITY TAX
Section
7-9-1   Tax Imposed
7-9-2   Collection from Customer
7-9-3   Remittance by Vendor
7-9-4   Failure to Remit
7-9-5   Local Hospitality Tax Account
7-9-6   Separability
7-9-7   Date passed
§ 7-9-1 TAX IMPOSED.
   There is hereby imposed a Local Hospitality Tax of two percent (2%) on the
gross proceeds of the sale of prepared meals and beverages in establishments
within the City of Dillon, SC (hereinafter "vendor"). Payment of the
hospitality tax established hereby shall be the liability of the customer.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)
§ 7-9-2 COLLECTION FROM CUSTOMER.
   The tax imposed by this ordinance shall be collected from the customer when
payment for meals or beverages is tendered and shall be held in trust for the
benefit of the city until remitted as provided in §
7-9-3 below.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)
§ 7-9-3 REMITTANCE BY VENDOR.
   Payment of the hospitality tax established herein shall be remitted by the
vendor to the City of Dillon, SC on a monthly basis, along with such return or
form as may be established by the city for such purposes, not later than the
twentieth day of the month and shall cover the tax due for the previous month.
Any tax not timely remitted shall be subject to a penalty of five percent (5%)
of the sum owed for each month or portion thereof until paid. The failure to
collect from the customer the tax imposed by this ordinance shall not relieve
the vendor from making the required remittance.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)
§ 7-9-4 FAILURE TO REMIT.
   The failure of any vendor subject to this ordinance to remit to the city the
tax imposed by the provisions of this ordinance shall constitute a misdemeanor
punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500) or
imprisonment for up to thirty (30) days, or both.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)
§ 7-9-5 LOCAL HOSPITALITY TAX ACCOUNT.
   There is hereby established a special account to be known as the Local
Hospitality Tax Account into which the taxes remitted shall be deposited by the
city and used solely for the purposes provided by law.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)
§ 7-9-6 SEPARABILITY.
   This ordinance is subject to the constitution and the laws of the State of
South Carolina. If any section, phrase, sentence or portion of this ordinance
is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions thereof.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)
§ 7-9-7 DATE PASSED.
   This ordinance shall become effective on January 1, 2004.
(Ord. 03-18, passed 9-8-2003)

§ 8-1-1 ADOPTION OF STATE LAW.
   There is hereby adopted by reference and made a part hereof as if set out in
full those provisions of state law known as the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic
on Highways as contained in S.C. Code, Title 56, Chapter 5.
(1977 Code, § 8-1001)

Code § 56-5-6150
Editorial Note: The cited state law may be incorporated by reference in an
ordinance by municipalities. Op. Atty. Gen., No. 2460, p. 125 (1967-68).
Municipalities may further regulate traffic provided the additional regulations
do not conflict with state law, see S.C. Code §§ 56-5-30, 56-5-710.
§ 8-1-2 ONLY LICENSED OPERATORS MAY DRIVE VEHICLES.
   No motor vehicle shall be operated upon the streets of the city other than
by a properly licensed driver.
(1977 Code, § 8-1002)
State Law Reference:
   State license required, S.C. Code § 56-1-20
§ 8-1-3 SPEED LIMIT.
   The speed limits within the city shall be as posted.
(1977 Code, § 8-1004)
§ 8-1-4 POWERS AND DUTIES OF CITY MANAGER.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided by this article, the City Manager, or his
designate, upon approval of the Council, shall have the power and is hereby
authorized to regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the
corporate limits of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or
markers indicating prohibited or limited parking, restricted speed areas, one-
way streets, play streets, through or arterial streets, stop streets, parking
meter spaces in parking meter zones, "U" turns, school zones, hospital zones,
loading or unloading zones, quiet zones, and other signs, markers and official
traffic control devices indicating the place or manner of operating or parking
vehicles within the city.
   (B)   Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, the City Manager or his
designate, upon approval of the Council, shall have power and is hereby
authorized to regulate the movement of pedestrians upon the streets and
sidewalks of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs, markers, or
devices indicating the flow of pedestrian traffic.
   (C)   Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, the City Manager or his
designate, upon approval of the Council, shall have power and is hereby
authorized to designate bus stops and taxicab stands and to erect signs
prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than busses and taxicabs at their
respective stops and stands.
   (D)   Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, the City Manager, or his
designate, upon approval of the Council, shall have power and is hereby
authorized to designate truck routes and to regulate the parking of vehicles of
various sizes and weights.
   (E)   Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, the City Manager, or his
designate, upon approval of the Council, shall have power and is authorized to
mark off traffic lanes on streets and parts of streets indicating and directing
the flow of traffic.
   (F)   The City Manager, or his designate, shall have power and is authorized
to secure all necessary signs, markers or official traffic control devices to
be erected or placed on any street or part of a street when the action is
deemed necessary.
   (G)   The existence of signs, markers or official traffic control devices at
any place within the city shall be prima facie evidence that the signs,
markers, or official traffic control devices were erected or placed by and at
the direction of the city and in accordance with the provisions of this
section.
   (H)   All of the orders issued by the City Manager pursuant to this section
shall be in writing and filed with the Clerk and shall be approved by the
Council.
   (I)   Any person failing or refusing to comply with the directions indicated
on any sign or marker, or with any official traffic control device, erected or
placed in accordance with the provisions of this section when so placed or
erected, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
§ 8-1-5 BLOCKING TRAFFIC.
   No person shall by any show or other performance or act wilfully block the
traffic on any of the streets of the city; provided, that this section shall
not apply to authorized work on the streets, if a convenient detour is
provided.
(1977 Code, § 8-1006)
§ 8-1-6 CRUISING PROHIBITED IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS; PENALTIES.
   (A)   Cruising as defined herein is hereby prohibited.
   (B)   For the purposes of this section, the following definitions apply:
      (1)   RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT.    A territory contiguous to and including a
street or highway within the city and which has been designated as R-12, R-7,
R-5, or MH Districts under the zoning laws of the city.
      (2)   POLICE CHECK POINT. Any place designated by a city police officer
for the purpose of regulating and controlling traffic, when a city police
officer is present at said place.
      (3)   STREET; HIGHWAY. The entire width between boundary lines of every
way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public
for purposes of vehicular traffic.
      (4)   CRUISING. Passing a police check point which has been established
on a street or highway located in a residential area in a motor vehicle more
than three (3) times within a two (2) hour period, after having been given
written notice after the third passing in the same direction, that passing the
police check point a fourth time in the same direction shall constitute a
violation of this section.
   (C)   The penalty for a first conviction of this section shall be a fine not
exceeding twenty-five dollars ($25). The penalty for a second or subsequent
conviction within a one (1) year period shall be a fine not exceeding fifty
dollars ($50).
   (D)   This section shall not apply to the following vehicles: emergency
vehicles on patrol, taxicabs for hire, and other business vehicles being driven
for business purposes.
(Am. Ord. 07-19, passed 9-10-2007)
Cross Reference:
   Zoning of residential areas, Sec.
5-4-55 et seq.
§ 8-1-7 CARELESS OPERATION OF A VEHICLE PROHIBITED; PENALTIES ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle without
care and caution and full regard for safety of persons or property. Any person
failing to do so shall be guilty of careless driving or riding. The operation
of any vehicle when the same or any of its appliances is not in proper or safe
condition shall be prima facie evidence of careless driving or riding; careless
operation is unlawful and may be a lesser included offense of reckless driving.
   (B)   It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to
perform any act required in this section.
   (C)   The fines for this offense are hereby established as follows:
 
Offense                                                                    Fine
Ten (10) miles per hour (MPH) or less above speed limit                    $43
More than ten (10) miles per hour (MPH) above speed limit but less than    $68
fifteen (15) MPH
More than fifteen (15) MPH above the speed limit but less than twenty-five $93
(25) MPH
More than twenty-five (25) MPH above speed limit                           $237
Such charges may be adjusted from time to time in line with other code
violations and as is permitted by law.
 
   (D)   It is the expressed and stated intent of Council that in plea
bargaining situations when this offense is employed, no part of the fine will
be suspended and no partial pay arrangements extended.
(Ord. 90-11, passed 6-1990)
§ 8-1-8 TRUCK ROUTES.
   (A)   Definitions.
      (1)   (a)   NO TRUCK ZONE - An area comprised of all roads within the
following perimeter:
 
No Truck Zone
East Main Street between U. S. Route 301- Highway 301 and MacArthur Avenue
West Main Street between Railroad Avenue and 11th Avenue
Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. between S. C. Route 9-Radford Blvd. and West Main
Street
 
         (b)   Trucks, as defined in this ordinance, are not allowed in the No
Truck Zone unless they are delivering to or taking on freight from a business
located within the No Truck Zone or engaged in public service along such
streets within the No Truck Zone.
         (c)   Further, such limitation shall not apply to trucks/drivers going
to and from home when their residence is on a street which intersects Martin
Luther King, Jr. Blvd; provided, however, a permit granting permission has been
obtained from the City of Dillon Code Enforcement Office. The permit shall be
valid only when in possession of the applicant to whom it was issued for such
truck.
      (2)   Truck - A vehicle in excess of two (2) tons in weight, having ten
(10) wheels or more.
      (3)   Truck Route - Designated roads which trucks shall use to travel
around the No Truck Zone.
   (B)   Thru Traffic.
      All trucks which are traveling thru the Dillon area to destinations
outside of the No Truck Zone are prohibited from entering the city limits
portion of the No Truck Zone. All such trucks shall instead use the Dillon
Truck Route which is comprised of S.C. Route 57, Lockemy Highway, U.S. Route
301-Highway 301, S.C. Route 9-Radford Blvd., and East Main Street between
Deerwood Avenue and U.S. Highway 301-Highway 301 of the city limits.
   (C)   Truck Making Deliveries or Pick-Ups Inside the No Truck Zone.
      Trucks are allowed to enter the No Truck Zone to deliver or to pick-up
freight from businesses located within the zone. Such trucks must have a bill
of lading which verifies the point of delivery or pick-up.
   (D)   Intra-City Conveyance.
      All trucks conducting Intra-City Conveyance shall use the most direct
route from their point of origin within the city limits to their destination
inside the city limits.
   (E)   Penalty Provision.
      Violators of any and all provision of this ordinance shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the following fines:
 
First (1st) Offense         One Hundred Dollars   ($100)
Second (2nd) Offense        Two Hundred Dollars   ($200)
Third (3rd) Offense         Three Hundred Dollars ($300)
Fourth (4th) Offense        Four Hundred Dollars  ($400)
Fifth (5th) Offense & above Five Hundred Dollars  ($500)
 
   (F)   Separability.
      If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this
ordinance is for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and
independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the
remaining portion thereof.
   (G)   That this ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
the earliest date permitted by law.
   (H)   All ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are hereby repealed.
(Ord. 01-27, passed 12-10-2001)
ARTICLE B: PARKING REGULATIONS
§ 8-1-21 DESIGNATION OF "HANDICAPPED ONLY" PARKING PLACES, PENALTIES FOR
VIOLATION.
   (A)   At least one (1) "Handicapped Parking Only" space shall be designated
by a proper sign for the area near any federal building within the city.
   (B)   The City Council is hereby given the authority to designate from time
to time other “Handicapped Parking Only” spaces within the city by method of a
duly made and adopted motion at a regular Council meeting. Any space so
designated for handicapped parking only must be indicated by a proper sign.
   (C)   Any vehicle parking in a properly marked "Handicapped Parking Only"
space must have displayed in plain sight an authorized sticker, license plate
or decal which states that the driver or a passenger in the vehicle is
handicapped. An authorized sticker as referred to above means one which is
obtained through a properly licensed physician or a license or sticker which is
issued by the state.
   (D)   The driver of any vehicle which is found parked in a properly marked
handicapped parking only space and which vehicle does not have displayed a duly
authorized handicapped sticker, license or decal shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction shall be subject up to the maximum fines and
penalties and/or imprisonment as allowed by the South Carolina Code of Laws
that may be imposed in a municipal or magistrate’s court for each subsequent
offense. Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues constitutes a
separate offense. Punishment for violation shall not relieve the offender of
liability and costs provided for herein.
(Am. Ord. 10-02, passed 3-8-2010)
Cross reference:
   Policy of non-discrimination against handicapped, Sec.
1-4-7,
1-4-8.
State Law Reference:
   Municipal duty to designate spaces for handicapped, S.C. Code § 56-3-1965
§ 8-1-22 DESIGNATION OF TWO (2) HOUR PARKING ZONES; PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   There is established two (2) hour parking zone on all marked parking
spaces on the public streets in the city, except the streets around the
courthouse and the city/county complex. The City Manager shall be responsible
for posting appropriate signs of at least three (3) per block.
   (B)   The driver of any vehicle which is found parked in a two (2) hour
parking space in excess of the two (2) hour time limit, and/or move their
vehicles from one (1) space to another, shall be subject to a fine of twenty-
five dollars ($ 25) for the first and second offense. Third offense is subject
to towing.
   (C)   This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its
adoption.
(Am. Ord. 00-01, passed 2-14-2000)

§ 9-2-1 ASSAULT AND BATTERY; BREACH OF PEACE; DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any assault and battery, or
assault, or engage in any breach of peace, within the corporate limits of the
city, or to engage in any riotous or disorderly conduct unbecoming a good
citizen. Disorderly conduct is hereby further defined as follows:
   (A)   Any person shall act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another
whereby any person is placed in fear of safety of his life, limb, or health;
   (B)   Any person who shall endanger lawful pursuits of another by acts of
violence, angry threats, and abusive conduct;
   (C)   Any person who utters while in a state of anger in the presence of
another any lewd or obscene words or epithets;
   (D)   Any person who shall act in a dangerous manner towards others.
(Ord. CM-89-30, passed 10-10-1989)
State Law Reference:
   Public disorderly conduct, S.C. Code § 16-17-530
§ 9-2-2 WEAPONS; CARRYING WHEN CONCEALED.
   Any person carrying any pistol, dirk, slingshot, metal knucks, razor or
other deadly weapon usually used for the infliction of personal injury
concealed about his person within the corporate limits of the city shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall forfeit to the city
the weapon so carried concealed and be fined in the sum of not more than one
hundred dollars ($100) and not less than twenty dollars ($20) or imprisoned not
more than thirty (30) nor less than ten (10) days in the discretion of the
court. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to apply to persons carrying
concealed weapons upon their own premises or to peace officers in the actual
discharge of their duties.
(1977 Code, § 9-1027)
§ 9-2-3 SAME; DISCHARGING IN OR NEAR STREETS, ETC.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully discharge any gun, pistol or
other firearm or use any slingshot, slungshot or other missile on or near any
of the streets, squares or avenues of the city.
(1977 Code, § 9-1028)
§ 9-2-4 SAME; DISCHARGING NEAR BUILDINGS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully discharge any gun, pistol or
other firearms, or to wilfully shoot or use any air rifle or other gun
discharging or emitting metal shots or to use any slingshot or other missile,
within three hundred (300) feet of any dwelling house or building occupied as a
place of business within the corporate limits of the city.
(1977 Code, § 9-1029)
§ 9-2-5 LOUD AND BOISTEROUS TALKING; INDECENT LANGUAGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in loud and boisterous
talking, so as to become a nuisance, or to use any form of profanity or
indecent language on the streets or in a gathering, audience or assembly or in
any public place whatsoever, within the corporate limits of the city.
(1977 Code, § 9-1018)
§ 9-2-6 NOISES GENERALLY.
   (A)   The creation and continuation of any loud, disturbing and unnecessary
noises in the city is hereby prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to
cause, make or contribute to creating any loud or disturbing noise of a
character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to the life or health of
any individual or so as to disturb the quiet and peace of any citizen of the
city. The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing,
annoying, and unnecessary noises in violation of this section, but the
enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive.
      (1)   Blowing Horns. The sounding or blowing of any horn or signal device
on any automobile, motorcycle, motor bus, or other vehicle, except as a danger
signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control, or if in
motion only as a danger signal; the creation by means of any signal device of
any loud or harsh noise; and the sounding of the device for any unnecessary
period of time.
      (2)   Radios and Phonographs. The playing of any radio, phonograph,
piccolo or any musical instrument in a manner or with a volume as to annoy or
disturb any person, or the playing of an instrument in a manner as to annoy or
disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any person of ordinary sensibilities in
any dwelling, hotel, or other residence.
      (3)   Pets. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent
or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons of
ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity.
      (4)   Use of Vehicle. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so
out of repair, so loaded or used or repaired in a manner as to create loud or
unnecessary noises, particularly grating, grinding, rattling, riveting or other
disturbing noises.
      (5)   Blowing Whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any
stationary boiler, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or
as a warning of danger.
      (6)   Exhaust Discharge. To discharge into the open air the exhaust from
any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle except
through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or
explosive noises therefrom.
      (7)   Devices Using. The use of any mechanical device operated by
compressed air, unless the noise created thereby is effectively muffled and
reduced.
      (8)   Building Operations. The erection (including excavations),
demolition, alteration or repair of any building in a residential or business
district other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., on weekdays,
except in cases of urgent necessity in the interest of public safety, and then
only with a permit from the Chief of Police.
      (9)   Noises near Schools, Hospitals and Churches. The creation of any
excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning,
library, sanatorium, hospital or court, while it is in session, or adjacent to
any church during church services, which interferes with the work or worship in
the place or institution; provided, that signs must be displayed in the streets
indicating that it is a school, hospital, church, library, sanatorium or court.
      (10)   Loading and Unloading Operations. The sounding of any bell or gong
attached to any building or premises which disturb the quiet or repose of any
person of ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity thereof.
      (11)   Bells or Gongs. The sounding of any bell or gong attached to any
building or premises which disturb the quiet or repose of any person of
ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity thereof.
      (12)   Hawking, Peddling or Soliciting.  Shouting, loud talking, crying
or soliciting by peddlers, hawkers, taxicab drivers, solicitors and vendors,
which disturb the quiet and peace of the neighborhood, or any person therein.
      (13)   Noises to Attract Attention. The use of any drum, loudspeaker or
other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any
performance or event, show, sale or the display or advertisement of merchandise
by the creation of noise.
      (14)   Loudspeakers or Amplifiers on Vehicles. The use of any mechanical
loudspeakers or amplifiers on trucks, airplanes or other vehicles for
advertising or other purposes, except by special permission of the Mayor.
      (15)   Business Noises at Night near Residences.  The operation of any
garage, filling station, auto repair business, taxicab business, plant, store,
factory or other place of business between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
in a manner as to create loud and disturbing noises, of a frequency or volume
as to annoy or disturb the quiet and comfort of any citizen and particularly
the creating of disturbing noises of a frequency and volume as to annoy or
disturb the quiet, comfort, peace or repose of any person of ordinary
sensibilities in any dwelling, hotel, boardinghouse or other type of residence.
   (B)   Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1977 Code, § 9-1019)
§ 9-2-7 DISORDERLY HOUSES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain a disorderly house
or any premises within the corporate limits where card playing or games of
chance are permitted, or where people are allowed to congregate and talk loudly
to the annoyance of the neighborhood.
(1977 Code, § 9-1008)
§ 9-2-8 DISTURBING PUBLIC GATHERINGS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully disturb any public gathering
or audience of any kind by any loud talking, whispering, whistling or loud
noise of any kind or by giving a false alarm, or in any other way, within the
corporate limits.
(1977 Code, § 9-1009)
§ 9-2-9 DRUNKENNESS; INDECENT CONDUCT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be found drunk or intoxicated,
or in any way conducting himself in an indecent manner on the streets of the
city or in any other public place within the city.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to publicly engage
in the drinking of alcoholic liquors, beer, ale, porter, or wine or any other
similar malt or fermented beverage.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to engage in the
drinking of alcoholic liquors, beer, ale, porter, wine or any other similar
malt or fermented beverage upon any premises which an athletic contest is being
conducted.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to drink alcoholic
liquors, beer, ale, porter, wine or any other similar malt or fermented
beverages on the premises of any retail, wholesale or manufacturing alcoholic
liquor business establishment.
(Ord. CM-90-14, passed 7-9-1990)
State Law Reference:
   Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages in vehicles. S.C. Code
§ 61-4-110
§ 9-2-10 INTERFERENCE WITH POLICE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, obstruct, use abusive
language or oppose, resist, strike or threaten a police officer or other
officer of the city, while in the discharge of his duty. It shall also be
unlawful for any person to refuse or fail to obey the summons or command of any
police officer or other officer when summoned to aid and assist him in the
discharge of his duties.
(1977 Code, § 9-1021)
State Law Reference:
   Impersonating law enforcement officer, S.C. Code § 16-7-20
§ 9-2-11 PRISONERS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person under arrest by the city officials or
for any prisoner of the city to make or effect his escape or to endeavor to
attempt to do so, or for any person to aid, abet, encourage or procure any
person under arrest or prisoner to do so. It shall be unlawful for any person
except city officials to take anything to do or in any way communicate with any
prisoner confined in the guardhouse or at work upon the public works of the
city unless leave so to do shall have first been obtained from the City Manager
or Chief of Police.
(1977 Code, § 9-1022)
§ 9-2-12 TRAINS; SPEED.
   It shall be unlawful for any train or locomotive of any railroad, upon any
railway, passing through the city to pass through the city at a rate of speed
exceeding sixty (60) miles per hour.
(1977 Code, § 9-1026)
§ 9-2-13 INDECENT EXPOSURE.
   Any person who shall be guilty of willful and malicious indecent exposure of
his person in any public place, on property of others, or in view of any person
on any street or highway shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction,
shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment or both in the discretion of the
court.
(Ord. 96-20, passed 10-14-1996)
§ 9-2-14 CURFEW FOR MINORS.
   (A)   Definitions. For purpose of enforcing and interpreting this section,
the following definitions shall control:
      (1)   A "minor" shall mean any person under seventeen (17) years of age.
      (2)   A "parent" shall mean a person who is the natural or adoptive
parent of a minor. As used herein, "parent" shall also include a court
appointed guardian or other person who is eighteen (18) years of age or older,
authorized by the parent, by a court order, or by a court appointed guardian to
have the care and custody of a minor.
      (3)   A "guardian" shall mean any person to whom custody of a minor has
been given by court order.
      (4)   An emergency shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
fire, natural disaster, vehicular accident, or obtaining immediate medical care
for another person.
      (5)   A public "place" means any place to which the public or a
substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to,
streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment
houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops.
   (B)   Offenses.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for a minor to purposefully remain, walk, run,
stand, drive or ride about in or upon any public place in the city, between the
hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for the parent having legal custody of a minor
to knowingly allow or permit the minor to be in violation of the curfew imposed
in subsection(B)(1) of this ordinance.
   (C)   Defenses. It is a defense to prosecution under §
9-2-14 of this ordinance if any of the following exist.
      (1)   The minor was accompanied by a parent or guardian;
      (2)   The minor was accompanied by another adult approved by the parent
or guardian of the minor;
      (3)   The minor was on an emergency errand;
      (4)   The minor was attending or going directly to or coming directly
from a school, community, government or religious activity;
      (5)   The minor was engaged in or going directly to or coming directly
from a lawful employment activity;
      (6)   The minor was on the sidewalk of the place where the minor resides
or on the sidewalk of a place where the minor has permission from his/her
parent or guardian to be or on the sidewalk of a next-door neighbor who has not
communicated an objection to this activity by the minor to any police officer.
      (7)   The minor was upon an errand directed by his/her parent or
guardian;
      (8)   The minor was in a motor vehicle involved in intrastate or
interstate transportation for which passage through the curfew area is the most
direct route;
      (9)   The minor was legitimately exercising his or his First Amendment
rights protected by the United States Constitution, including but not limited
to the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly.
   (D)   Enforcement Procedure.
      (1)   First Offense. Any police officer, upon finding a minor in
violation of section (B) of this ordinance, shall determine the name and
address of the minor, and the name and address of the minor's parent or
guardian. A warning notice shall be forwarded to the Juvenile Division of the
Dillon Police Department, which shall send a letter to the parent or guardian
of the minor advising of the fact that the minor was found in violation of this
ordinance, and soliciting cooperation from the parent or guardian to avoid any
subsequent violations of this ordinance by the offending minor.
      (2)   Second Offense. Any police officer, upon finding that a minor is in
violation of section (B)(1), and once previously warned as required in section
(D)(1) shall again determine the minor's name and address and the name and
address of the minor's parents or guardian. A second warning notice shall be
issued to and served upon the minor, who shall be ordered to immediately go
home by the most direct means and route. A copy of the second warning notice
shall be forwarded to the Juvenile Division of the Dillon Police Department
which shall schedule a personal conference with the minor's parent or guardian
and the minor concerning the necessity of the enforcement of this ordinance and
the city's expectations of parental control of minors.
      (3)   Third Offense. Any police officer, upon finding that a minor in
violation of section (B) and that the minor has twice previously been found in
violation of section (B) and twice previously warned as required in section (D)
(1) and section (D)(2) shall again determine the minor's name and address and
the name and address of the minor's parent/guardian. A complaint shall then be
filed against the minor's parents/guardians in municipal court for violation of
section (B)(2) hereof. The City Police Department shall be responsible for
filing all necessary legal papers pursuant to this ordinance, supply the
municipal court with all necessary documentation, and provide such testimony as
be required to pursue any prosecution under this ordinance against any minor or
parent/guardian.
   (E)   Penalties.
      (1)   Any minor violating the provisions of this ordinance shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor as defined in the South Carolina Code of Laws.
      (2)   A parent or guardian of a minor violating this ordinance shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor as defined in the South Carolina Code of Laws.
      (3)   In assessing punishment for either a parent, guardian or minor, the
municipal court is encouraged to consider utilization of the community service
program.
(Ord. 97-03, passed 2-10-1997)

§ 9-3-1 DAMAGING PROPERTY; GENERALLY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to play around or in any way romp over,
or damage or deface, or spoil in any way any property of any person, including
any and all kinds of buildings, or any kind of a building in the process of
construction, or any personal property, within the corporate limits.
(1977 Code, § 9-1006)
State Law Reference:
   Malicious injury to personal property, S.C. Code § 16-11-510

lamp, or bridge or any other property of the city.
(1977 Code, § 9-1007)
§ 9-3-3 SAME; POSTING PLACARDS AND POSTERS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to post any placards, posters or
advertisements of like kind on any public property in the city or upon any
private property in the city without the consent of the owner. (1977 Code, § 9-
1002)
§ 9-3-4 SAME; FALSE ADVERTISING.
   Any person advertising by newspapers, radio, posters or otherwise,
representing that he is operating, offering or maintaining "fire sales," wreck
sales," "closing or going out of business sales" and similar businesses,
whereby the public is led to believe that they are being offered merchandise at
reduced rates on account of "fires," "wrecks," "bankruptcy," "closing out or
discontinuance of business," when in fact the sales are not bona fide, but are
fakes and frauds, and the advertisements and representations are untrue and
false, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1977 Code, § 9-1003)
State Law Reference:
   False advertising, S.C. Code § 39-1-20
§ 9-3-5 DRAWING AND UTTERING FRAUDULENT CHECK, DRAFT OR OTHER WRITTEN ORDER.
   (A)   Pursuant to S.C. Code § 34-11-90, the city hereby adopts and
incorporates into this Code, S.C. Code §§ 34-11-60 through 34-11-100. A
violation of any of these provisions shall be a misdemeanor, punishable as
provided in the statutes.
   (B)   In addition to the penalties provided in paragraph (A), a charge of
twenty-five dollars ($25) shall be imposed on anyone issuing a bad check to the
city for the payment of any municipal bill or fee.
(Ord. CM-42, passed 9-19-1985; Am. Ord. 99-25, passed 1-18-2000)
Cross reference:
   Charges for bad checks received as payment for water and sewer charges, Sec.
4-4-14
§ 9-3-6 NEIGHBORHOOD PARK HOURS.
   (A)   The following City Neighborhood Parks shall be open for public use
beginning at sun up and ending at sundown due to not having adequate lighting
for activities. Anyone on the park property prior to sun up or after sundown
shall be guilty of the offense of trespass.
      (1)   Harmon Park (North 8th Avenue).
      (2)   Elizabeth Lane Park.
      (3)   West Calhoun Park.
      (4)   East Street Park.
   (B)   During the Neighborhood Park Hours, the City Neighborhood Parks shall
not be reserved for any special events or performances by any person or
organizations.
   (C)   The City Manager is hereby directed to place and maintain the
appropriate signage on all city parks in order to enforce the provisions of
this section.
(Ord. 94-16, passed 7-12-1994; Am. Ord. 10-05, passed 5-10-2010; Am. Ord. 12-
15, passed 10-8-2012)
§ 9-3-7 NEWSPAPER, HANDBILL, ADVERTISER, CIRCULAR DELIVERY CONTROLLED,
SUBSCRIPTIONS EXCLUDED.
   (A)   No newspaper, advertiser, circular handbill or such materials shall be
permitted to be delivered, thrown or placed in any fashion upon the driveway or
yard of any residence within the city. Delivery of newspapers, advertisers,
circulars or handbills may be made only through the mail delivery, or by
placing the material in an elevated box designated for this purpose and placed
at the curbside. This section shall not apply to subscriptions which are
delivered to persons who have paid subscriptions.
   (B)   No newspaper, advertiser, circular handbill or such materials shall be
permitted to be delivered, thrown or placed in any fashion upon any motor
vehicle within the corporate city limits of Dillon.
(Ord. CM-90-27, passed- -; Am. Ord. 10-13, passed 12-13-2010)
§ 9-3-8 DISTRIBUTION OF NEWSPAPERS, ADVERTISERS, CIRCULARS, HANDBILLS, FROM
RIGHT-OF-WAY PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful to sell, purchase or distribute newspapers,
advertisers, circulars, handbills or other similar literature from or in the
roadway or highway (traveled portion of the street). Violation of this offense
is punishable by a fine of ten dollars ($10).
(Ord. CM-90-28, passed- -)
CHAPTER 4: OFFENSES AGAINST MORALITY
Section
9-4-1   Gambling; Generally
9-4-2   Same; Slot Machines and Punch Boards
§ 9-4-1 GAMBLING; GENERALLY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to play at any game or do any act, the
result whereof is determined by chance. Nor shall it be lawful for any person
to bet or wager money or other articles or things upon any game, matter or
thing.
(1977 Code, § 9-1012)
Cross reference:
   Gambling in poolrooms and bowling alleys, Sec.
7-4-4
State Law Reference:
   Gambling and lotteries, S.C. Code §§ 16-19-10 et seq.
§ 9-4-2 SAME; SLOT MACHINES AND PUNCH BOARDS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep on his premises, or
operate within the city any vending or slot machine, punchboard, pullboard or
other device pertaining to games of chance of whatever name or kind, except
automatic weighing, measuring, musical and vending machines, which are so
constructed as to give a certain uniform and fair return in value for each coin
deposited therein and in which there is no element of change; provided, that
this section is also intended to prohibit all vending, slot machines,
punchboards, pullboards or different pictures, words, or symbols at different
plays, or different numbers, whether in words or figures, or which deposit
tokens or coins at irregular intervals or in varying numbers to the player or
in the machine.
   (B)   Any vending or slot machine, punchboard, pullboard or other device
pertaining to games of chance, prohibited by this section, shall be seized by
any officer of the city and shall be held by the officer until the offending
owner or custodian thereof is tried under this section. If the owner is
convicted the machine or device shall be destroyed, otherwise it shall be
returned to the owner.
(1977 Code, § 9-1013)
State Law Reference:
   Minor playing pinball machines, S.C. Code § 20-7-8915
CHAPTER 5: DRUG OFFENSES
Section
Article A: Synthetic Methadone
   
9-5-1   Findings of Fact
   
9-5-2   Prohibitions
   
9-5-3   Penalties
Article B: Synthetic Marijuana
   
9-5-10   Findings and Determination
   
9-5-11   Definition
   
9-5-12   Advertisement, Sale, and Use Prohibited
   
9-5-13   Penalties
ARTICLE A: SYNTHETIC METHADONE
§ 9-5-1 FINDINGS OF FACT.
   (A)   The City of Dillon (the "city"), is an incorporated municipality
located in Dillon County, South Carolina, and as such, possesses all powers
granted to municipalities by the Constitution and Laws of the State of South
Carolina, including S.C. § 5-7-30, relating to the regulation of streets,
markets, and public health.
   (B)   After a careful study of the issue, the City Council of the city
("Council") has determined that various preparations of the chemicals
Methylone, Mephedrone, Methoxymethcathinone, Methylenedioxypyrovalerone, and
Fluoromethcathinone are being created, manufactured, marketed, sold,
distributed, possessed, and used within the municipal limits of the city. Such
substances are well documented as dangerous "synthetic" or "designer" drugs and
pose real and present danger to public health in the city.
   (C)   None of Methylone, Mephedrone, Methoxymethcathinone,
Methylenedioxypyrovalerone, and Fluoromethcathinone is a scheduled substance or
is otherwise prohibited by state or federal law as to manufacture, sale,
possession, or use.
(Ord. 11-14, passed 10-10-2011)
§ 9-5-2 PROHIBITIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to create, manufacture, market, sell,
distribute, possess, or use Methylone, Mephedrone, Methoxymethcathinone,
Methylenedioxypyrovalerone, and Fluoromethcathinone or any preparation or
compound containing such substances in any form within the municipal limits of
the city.
(Ord. 11-14, passed 10-10-2011)
§ 9-5-3 PENALTIES.
   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of §
9-5-2 shall be subject to a civil fine of not greater than five thousand
dollars ($5,000). Imposition of such fine shall not be deemed a criminal
penalty, and shall not give rise to any disability or legal disadvantage based
on conviction of a criminal offense.
(Ord. 11-14, passed 10-10-2011)
ARTICLE B: SYNTHETIC MARIJUANA
§ 9-5-10 FINDINGS AND DETERMINATIONS.
   (A)   The City of Dillon (the "city"), is an incorporated municipality
located in Dillon County, South Carolina, and as such, possesses all powers
granted to municipalities by the Constitution and Laws of the State of South
Carolina, including the powers enumerated in S.C. § 5-7-30, relating to the
regulation of streets, markets, and public health.
   (B)   This article is added to promote, protect, and provide for the health,
safety and welfare of the City of Dillon and its citizens.
   (C)   This article is necessary and proper due to the following:
      (1)   The city currently lacks an ordinance prohibiting and restricting
the use of synthetic marijuana;
      (2)   The absence of such ordinance may allow for the increased
prevalence of synthetic marijuana usage and dangers associated therewith in the
city;
      (3)   The adoption of ordinances related to the prohibition of synthetic
marijuana shall provide law enforcement with the necessary ordinances to
prevent drug use and drug-related crimes in the city;
      (4)   The prevention of drug use and drug-related crimes shall promote
the public health, safety, order, appearance and general welfare of all
citizens by providing for a safer and healthier city.
(Ord. 11-15, passed 10-10-2011)
§ 9-5-11 DEFINITION.
   As used in this article, the following term shall have the meaning indicated
in this section.
   SYNTHETIC MARIJUANA shall mean and refer to all chemical compounds intended
to replicate, mimic or cause a similar reaction to the effects of marijuana or
cannabis. Such compounds are known or marketed under such names as THC, HU-210,
Cannabicyclohexanol, JWH-018, JWH-073, K2, spice herbal incense, herbal smoking
blends, and other names. Further, SYNTHETIC MARIJUANA shall be considered an
illegal narcotic as further provided in the City of Dillon Code.
(Ord. 11-15, passed 10-10-2011)
§ 9-5-12 ADVERTISEMENT, SALE, AND USE PROHIBITED.
   The advertisement, sale and use of synthetic marijuana is prohibited within
the City of Dillon.
(Ord. 11-15, passed 10-10-2011)
§ 9-5-13 PENALTIES.
   Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of
a misdemeanor and, upon conviction must be punished up to the maximum fines and
penalties as allowed by the South Carolina Code of Laws that may be imposed in
a municipal or magistrate’s court for each subsequent offense. Each day upon
which a violation occurs or continues constitutes a separate offense.
Punishment for violation shall not relieve the offender of liability and costs
provided for herein.
(Ord. 11-15, passed 10-10-2011)
CHAPTER 6: UNLAWFUL LOITERING
Section
9-6-1   Unlawful loitering, public property and rights-of-way
9-6-2   Police order to disperse
9-6-3   Penalty; continuing violations
9-6-4   Court order on jurisdictional limits
§ 9-6-1 UNLAWFUL LOITERING, PUBLIC PROPERTY AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on the public property and
rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the city limits with no apparent
purpose other than to intimidate others from entering onto the subject property
and rights-of-way, to establish control over subject property and rights-of-
way, and/or to conceal illegal activities thereon in such a manner as to:
   (A)   Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the
comfort and repose of any person;
   (B)   Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace;
   (C)   Obstruct or hinder the free passage of vehicles or pedestrians;
   (D)   Obstruct or interfere with any person lawfully on the subject property
and rights of way;
   (E)   Engage in begging;
   (F)   Engage in gambling;
   (G)   Engage in prostitution;
   (H)   Solicit or engage in any business, trade or commercial transaction
unless specifically authorized or licensed to do so;
   (I)   Unlawfully use or possess an unlawful drug; or
   (J)   Unlawfully use or possess alcoholic beverages, beer, or wine.
(Ord. 16-16, passed 12-12-2016; Am. Ord. 23-19, passed 11-13-2023)
§ 9-6-2 POLICE ORDER TO DISPERSE.
   When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in §
9-6-1 herein, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that
person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or
disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty
of a violation of this chapter. Any person who violates any of the provisions
of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as prescribed in §
9-6-3. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each
successive day continued.
(Ord. 16-16, passed 12-12-2016)
§ 9-6-3 PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS.
   Any person who is convicted of any violation of this ordinance, the court
before whom an offender shall be tried may sentence him to pay a fine not
exceeding the maximum fine permitted by law or serve a term not exceeding
thirty (30) days in jail, or both. Each day any violation of this chapter shall
continue, shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 16-16, passed 12-12-2016)
§ 9-6-4 COURT ORDER ON JURISDICTIONAL LIMITS.
   In addition to the penalty that may be imposed pursuant to §
9-6-3 above, any person who is arrested for and/or convicted of violating any
provision of this chapter may be subject to an order of the court which shall
impose a jurisdictional limit on said person prohibiting his presence in a
specific geographic area of the city. Failure to comply with the court order
shall constitute a violation of the court order and shall result in the
following: (1) in the case of a bond where jurisdictional limits have been
imposed, the bond may be revoked and the person shall be incarcerated until
trial; and/or (2) in the case of a sentence where jurisdictional limits have
been imposed, the suspended sentence may be revoked and the person shall be
incarcerated until the person has served the original sentence imposed by the
court without any portion thereof suspended.
(Ord. 16-16, passed 12-12-2016)
